column1: Chylomicronemia syndrome is a disorder in which the body does not break down fats (lipids) correctly.
Chylomicronemia syndrome can occur due to a rare genetic disorder in which a protein (enzyme) called lipoprotein lipase (LpL) is broken or missing.
When LpL is missing or broken, fat particles called chylomicrons build up in the blood.

Symptoms may start in infancy and include: - Abdominal pain due to pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) - Symptoms of nerve damage such as loss of feeling in the feet or legs, and memory loss - Yellow deposits of fatty material in the skin called xanthomas.
